question: Question 1 The peak of flood hydrograph due to a 3-hour duration storm in a catchment is 180 [latex] \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex]. The total rainfall depth is 6.6 cm. It can be assumed that the average infiltration loss is 0.2 cm/h. There are no other losses. The base flow is constant at a value of 30 [latex] \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex]. The peak value of the 3-hour unit hydrograph for this catchment (in [latex] \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex]) is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Step 1: Calculate effective rainfall (runoff depth): Infiltration loss = [latex] 0.2 , \text{cm/h} [/latex] for 3 hours = [latex] 0.6 , \text{cm} [/latex] Effective rainfall = [latex] 6.6 - 0.6 = 6.0 , \text{cm} [/latex] Step 2: Calculate direct runoff peak flow: Total peak discharge = [latex] 180 , \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex] Base flow = [latex] 30 , \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex] Direct runoff peak = [latex] 180 - 30 = 150 , \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex] Step 3: Compute peak of unit hydrograph: Since the rainfall depth (i.e., runoff) corresponds to 6.0 cm, then peak of 3-hour unit hydrograph = [latex] \frac{150}{6} = 25 , \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex] Answer: [latex] \boxed{25 , \text{m}^3/\text{s}} [/latex]

question: Question 2 In the context of the effect of drainage density on the run-off generation and the hydrograph at the catchment outlet, all other factors remaining the same, pick one or more CORRECT statement(s) from the choices given below.
solution: Understanding Drainage Density: Drainage density is defined as the total length of streams and rivers in a basin divided by the total area of the basin. [latex]\text{Drainage Density} = \frac{\text{Total Length of Streams}}{\text{Catchment Area}}[/latex] Effect on Runoff and Hydrograph: A higher drainage density means that water reaches the outlet faster, leading to a sharper and higher peak in the flood hydrograph and a shorter time base. A lower drainage density implies that water takes longer to concentrate, causing a broader hydrograph with a lower peak and a longer time base. Statement (A): This is incorrect. Lower drainage density leads to lower, not higher, flood peaks. Statement (B): Correct. Lower drainage density causes slower concentration of runoff and hence a lower peak in the hydrograph. Statement (C): Correct. Lower drainage density leads to slower runoff and hence a longer time base. Statement (D): Incorrect. Lower drainage density leads to longer, not shorter, time base. Final Answer: (B) and (C) are correct.

options.A: Lower drainage density results in higher peak in flood hydrograph compared to that when the drainage density is higher.
options.B: Lower drainage density results in lower peak in flood hydrograph compared to that when the drainage density is higher.
options.C: Lower drainage density results in a flood hydrograph with a longer time base compared to that when the drainage density is higher.
options.D: Lower drainage density results in a flood hydrograph with a shorter time base compared to that when the drainage density is higher.

question:
Question 3 The mean rainfall over a catchment has to be estimated. The data for four rain gauges located in and around the catchment is listed in the table. Which one of the following statements is correct: [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Rain gauge station }& P & Q & R & S \\
\hline
\text{Whether located inside the catchment} & Yes & Yes & Yes & No \\
\hline
\text{Thiessen weightage factor }& 0.25 & 0.50 & 0.10 & 0.15 \\
\hline
\text{Rainfall (mm)} & 100 & 110 & 100 & 125 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution: Given Data: Rainfall (mm): P = 100, Q = 110, R = 100, S = 125 Thiessen Weights: P = 0.25, Q = 0.50, R = 0.10, S = 0.15 1. Arithmetic Mean (Only Inside the Catchment) Stations considered: P, Q, R [latex] \text{Arithmetic Mean} = \frac{100 + 110 + 100}{3} = \frac{310}{3} = 103.33 \ \text{mm} [/latex] 2. Thiessen Mean (All Stations with Given Weights) [latex] \text{Thiessen Mean} = (0.25)(100) + (0.50)(110) + (0.10)(100) + (0.15)(125) \ = 25 + 55 + 10 + 18.75 = 108.75 \ \text{mm} [/latex] Conclusion: [latex] \text{Thiessen Mean (108.75 mm)} > \text{Arithmetic Mean (103.33 mm)} [/latex] Correct Option: (A) The estimate obtained from the Thiessen-mean method is greater than that obtained using the arithmetic-mean method.

options.A: The estimate obtained from the Thiessen-mean method is greater than that obtained using the arithmetic-mean method
options.B: The estimate obtained from the Thiessen-mean method is equal to that obtained using the arithmetic-mean method
options.C: The estimate obtained from the Thiessen-mean method is less than that obtained using the arithmetic-mean method
options.D: The Thiessen-mean method cannot be applied in this case

question: Question 4 A water resources project with an expected life of 25 years has to be designed for an acceptable risk of [latex]5 \%[/latex] against a design flood. The return period for the design flood (in years) is _________ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: To find the return period (T) for a given acceptable risk (R) over the project life (n), we use the formula: [latex] R = 1 - \left(1 - \frac{1}{T} \right)^n [/latex] Given: [latex] R = 0.05 [/latex] (5% acceptable risk) [latex] n = 25 [/latex] years Rearranging the formula to solve for T: [latex] 0.05 = 1 - \left(1 - \frac{1}{T} \right)^{25} [/latex] [latex] \left(1 - \frac{1}{T} \right)^{25} = 0.95 [/latex] Taking natural log on both sides: [latex] 25 \cdot \ln\left(1 - \frac{1}{T} \right) = \ln(0.95) [/latex] [latex] \ln\left(1 - \frac{1}{T} \right) = \frac{\ln(0.95)}{25} [/latex] [latex] 1 - \frac{1}{T} = e^{\frac{\ln(0.95)}{25}} [/latex] [latex] \frac{1}{T} = 1 - e^{\frac{\ln(0.95)}{25}} [/latex] Now calculate: [latex] \frac{1}{T} = 1 - e^{-0.002051} \approx 1 - 0.99795 = 0.00205 [/latex] [latex] T = \frac{1}{0.00205} \approx 487.8 [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{488} [/latex]

question: Question 5 To derive the total flood hydrograph at a catchment outlet from an isolated storm, the order in which the following methods are applied, from the first method to the last method, is P. Obtaining the hyetograph Q. Addition of baseflow R. Estimation of initial and infiltration losses S. Application of unit hydrograph
solution: To derive the total flood hydrograph at a catchment outlet from an isolated storm, the correct order of methods is: [latex]\text{Step 1: Obtain the hyetograph}[/latex] [latex]\text{Step 2: Estimate initial and infiltration losses to compute effective rainfall}[/latex] [latex]\text{Step 3: Apply unit hydrograph to derive direct runoff hydrograph (DRH)}[/latex] [latex]\text{Step 4: Add baseflow to DRH to get total flood hydrograph}[/latex] [latex]\text{Correct Order: P} \rightarrow \text{R} \rightarrow \text{S} \rightarrow \text{Q}[/latex]

Question 9 The return period of a large earthquake for a given region is 200 years. Assuming that earthquake occurrence follows Poisson's distribution, the probability that it will be exceeded at least once in 50 years is ______[latex]\% [/latex]. (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad \text { Risk } & =1-\left[\frac{\lambda^{r} \cdot e^{-\lambda}}{r !}\right] \\
& =1-\left[\frac{\lambda^{0} \cdot e^{-\lambda}}{0 !}\right] \\
\lambda & =n p=50 \times \frac{1}{200}=0.25 \\
\text { Now, } \quad \text { Risk } & =1-\left[e^{-0.25}\right] \\
& =0.2211 \text { or } 22.11 \%
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 10 The cross-section of a small river is sub-divided into seven segments of width [latex]1.5 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] each. The average depth, and velocity at different depths were measured during a field campaign at the middle of each segment width. The discharge computed by the velocity area method for the given data is ____ [latex]\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place).

& =\frac{\left(1.5+\frac{1.5}{2}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 1.5} \\
& =1.6875 \mathrm{~m}

Velocity } \\ \text { (m/s) } \\ \text { (3) }\end{array} & \begin{array}{c}\text { Segmental } \\ \text { discharge } \\ \left(\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}\right)=(1) \times(2) \times(3)\end{array} \\

question:
Question 11 A catchment may be idealized as a circle of radius [latex]30 \mathrm{~km}[/latex]. There are five rain gauges, one at the center of the catchment and four on the boundary (equi-spaced), as shown in the figure (not to scale). The annual rainfall recorded at these gauges in a particular year are given below. [latex]

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Gauge & \mathrm{G}_{1} & \mathrm{G}_{2} & \mathrm{G}_{3} & \mathrm{G}_{4} & \mathrm{G}_{5} \\
\hline
Rainfall (mm) & 910 & 930 & 925 & 895 & 905 \\
\hline
\end{array}

[/latex] Using the Thiessen polygon method, what is the average rainfall (in [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) over the catchment in that year ? ___
solution:
Radius of basin [latex]=30 \mathrm{~km}[/latex] We know that in Theissen polygon method, the polygons are obtained by joining the perpendicular bisectors of triangles formed, when various rain gauge stations are joined. The Theissen polygon in the given basin can be drawn as: Area under influence of station GI [latex]=30 \times 30=900 \mathrm{~km}^{2}[/latex] Area under influence of stations G2, G3, G4, G5 [latex]=\frac{\pi \times 30^{2}-900}{4}[/latex] [latex]=481.86 \mathrm{~km}^{2}[/latex] mean rainfall [latex]=\frac{\begin{array}{c}910 \times 900+481.86 \times 930+ \\ 481.86 \times 925+481.86 \times 895+ \\ 481.86 \times 905\end{array}}{900+481.86 \times 4}[/latex]

[latex]=912.56 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]

Question 16 A flood control structure having an expected life of n years is designed by
considering a flood of return period [latex]T  [/latex] years. When [latex]T=n  [/latex], and [latex]n\rightarrow \infty  [/latex], the
structure's hydrologic risk of failure in percentage is .
(round off to one decimal place)
solution:
Risk of failure [latex]=1-q^n=1-(1-p)^n=1-\left ( 1-\frac{1}{T} \right )^n [/latex] For 
[latex] T=n\rightarrow \infty [/latex] Risk of failure [latex] =1-\frac{1}{e}=0.632[/latex] % risk of failure = 0.632 x 100=63.2%

question: Question 19 The hyetograph in the figure corresponds to a rainfall event of 3 cm. If the rainfall event has produced a direct runoff of 1.6 cm, the [latex]\phi[/latex]-index of the event (in mm/hour,round off to one decimal place) would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Total rainfall } &=3 \mathrm{~cm} \\ \text { Total runoff } &=1.6 \mathrm{~cm} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \qquad\text { Total infiltration } &=3-1.6=1.4 \mathrm{~cm}\\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\text { W-index }&=\frac{\text { Total infiltration }}{\text { Total duration of storm }}\\ &=\frac{1.4}{(210 / 60)} \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{hr} \\ &=0.4 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{hr}=4 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{hr}\\ \text { As } \phi \text { -index }>\text { W-index }\qquad \qquad \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence storm of intensities 4 mm/hr and 3 mm/hr will not produce rainfall exam. [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi \text { -index } &=\frac{\text { Total infiltration in which rainfall excess occur }}{\text { Time period in which rainfall excess occur }} \\ &=\frac{\text { Total infiltration }-\text { Infiltration in which no rainfall excess occur }}{T_{\text {excess }}} \\ &=\frac{14 \mathrm{~mm}-\left(4 \times \frac{30}{60}+3 \times \frac{30}{60}\right) \mathrm{mm}}{\left(\frac{150}{60}\right) \mathrm{hr}} \\ &=4.2 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 A 12-hour unit hydrograph (of 1 cm excess rainfall) of a catchment is of a triangular shape with a base width of 144 hour and a peak discharge of [latex]23 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The area of the catchment (in [latex]\mathrm{~km}^{2}[/latex],round off to the nearest integer) is _______
solution: Area of hydrograph = Total direct runoff volume [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 23 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \times 144 \times &3600 \mathrm{sec}=\text { Area of catchment } \times \text { Runoff depth }\\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 23 \times 144 \times 3600 \mathrm{~m}^{3} &=A \times \frac{1}{100} \mathrm{~m} \\ A &=596.16 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \\ \therefore \quad \text{ Area of catchment }&=596.16 \mathrm{~km}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 A tube-well of 20 cm diameter fully penetrates a horizontal, homogeneous and isotropic confined aquifer of infinite horizontal extent. The aquifer is of 30 m uniform thickness. A steady pumping at the rate of 40 litres/s from the well for a long time results in a steady drawdown of 4 m at the well face. The subsurface flow to the well due to pumping is steady, horizontal and Darcian and the radius of influence of the well is 245 m. The hydraulic conductivity of the aquifer (in m/day,round off to integer) is ______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 40 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} &=\frac{2 \pi k \times 30 \mathrm{~m} \times 4 \mathrm{~m}}{\ln \left(\frac{245}{0.1}\right)} \\ k &=4.14 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{or, } \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad k &=35.77 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{d} \\ &\approx 36 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{d} (\text{ round off to nearest integer}) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 22 The value of abscissa (x) and ordinate (y) of a curve are as follows: [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|} \hline x & y \\ \hline 2.0 & 5.00 \\ \hline 2.5 & 7.25 \\ \hline 3.0 & 10.00 \\ \hline 3.5 & 13.25 \\ \hline 4.0 & 17.00 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] By Simpson's [latex]1 / 3^{\mathrm{rd}}[/latex] rule, the area under the curve (round off to two decimal places) is ______________
solution: d = 0.5 unit [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\frac{d}{3}\left[\left(y_{1}+y_{5}\right)+4\left(y_{2}+y_{4}\right)+2 y_{3}\right] \\ &=\frac{0.5}{3}[(5+17)+4(7.25+13.25)+2 \times 10] \\ &=20.67 \text { unit }^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 Two reservoirs are connected through a homogeneous and isotropic aquifer having hydraulic conductivity (K) of 25 m/day and effective porosity [latex](\eta)[/latex] of 0.3 as shown in the figure (not to scale). Ground water is flowing in the aquifer at the steady state. If water in Reservoir 1 is contaminated then the time (in days, round off to one decimal place) taken by the contaminated water to reach to Reservoir 2 will be _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k&=25 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{d} \\ n&=0.3 \\ i&=\frac{20 \mathrm{~m}}{2000 \mathrm{~m}}=0.01 \\ V&=k i \\ V_{s}&=\frac{V}{n} \\ t&=\frac{l}{V_{s}} \\ t&=2400 \mathrm{days} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 Muskingum method is used in
solution: Muskingum method is used in hydrological channel routing

question:
Question 27 In a homogeneous unconfined aquifer of area 3.00 [latex]km^2[/latex], the water table was at an elevation
of 102.00 m. After a natural recharge of volume 0.90 million cubic meter ([latex]Mm^2[/latex]), the water
table rose to 103.20 m. After this recharge, ground water pumping took place and the
water table dropped down to 101.020 m. The volume of ground water pumped after the
natural recharge, expressed (in [latex]Mm^2[/latex] and round off to two decimal places), is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_R&=0.9Mm^3\\ V&=3 \times (103.2-102)\\ y_s \; \text{or}\; y_R&=\frac{VR}{V}=\frac{0.9}{3.6}\\ \text{Now,}\;\; y_s&=\frac{V_D}{V}\\ V_D&=\frac{0.9}{3.6}[3 \times (103.2-101.2)]\\ V_D&=1.5Mm^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 28 The probability that a 50 year flood may NOT occur at all during 25 years life of a project
(round off to two decimal places), is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=\frac{1}{T}=\frac{1}{50}=0.02 \\ q&=1-P=0.98 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Probability of non-occurance of an event is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Assurance} &= q^n \\ &= (0.98)^{25}\\ &= 0.603 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The ordinates, u, of a 2-hour unit hydrograph (i.e., for 1 cm of effective rain), for a catchment are shown in the table. A 6-hour storm occurs over the catchment such that the effective rainfall intensity is 1 cm/hour for the first two hours, zero for the next two hours, and 0.5 cm/hour for the last two hours. If the base flow is constant at 5 [latex]m^3/s[/latex], the peak flow due to this storm (in [latex]m^3/s[/latex],round off to 1 decimal place) will be _____
solution: Rainfall excess in 1st two hours, [latex]R_1=1cm/hr \times 2 hr=2cm[/latex] Rainfall excess in 2nd two hours [latex]R_2=0[/latex] Rainfall excess in 3rd two hours, [latex]R_3=0.5cm/hr \times 2 hr=1cm[/latex]

question: Question 30 An inflow hydrograph is routed through a reservoir to produce an outflow hydrograph. The peak flow of the inflow hydrograph is [latex]P_I[/latex] and the time of occurrence of the peak is [latex]t_I[/latex]. The peak flow of the outflow hydrograph is [latex]P_O[/latex] and the time of occurrence of the peak is [latex]t_O[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is correct?
solution: The outflow from the reservoir is uncontrolled therefore peak of outflow hydrograph will occur at the junction of inflow and outflow hydrograph. [latex]P_I \gt P_0[/latex] [latex]t_I \lt t_0[/latex]

question: Question 31 The hyetograph of a storm event of duration 140 minutesis shown in the figure. The infiltration capacity at the start of this event (t=0) is 17 mm/hour, which linearly decreases to 10 mm/hour after 40 minutes duration. As the event progresses, the infiltration rate further drops down linearly to attain a value of 4 mm/hour at t=100 minutes and remains constant thereafter till the end of the storm event. The value of the infiltration index, [latex]\phi[/latex] (in mm/hour, round off to 2 decimal places), is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=(4+8+15+10+8+3+1) \times \frac{20}{60} \\ &=16.33\; minute \\ Q&=(15-10) \times \frac{20}{60} +(10-8) \times \frac{20}{60} \\ &+(8-6) \times \frac{20}{60} +\frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times \frac{20}{60}+\frac{1}{2} \\ &+\frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times \frac{20}{60}+frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times \frac{20}{60}\\ &=4mm\\ W-index&=\frac{P-Q}{t}=\frac{16.33-4}{\frac{140}{60}}=5.28 mm/hr\\ \text{Since,} \; \phi & \geq W\\ \text{Assume, }\; \phi &=5.28 mm/hr\\ \Rightarrow \; \text{Corrected, }\phi &=\frac{16.33-4-4 \times \frac{20}{60}-3 \times \frac{20}{60}-1 \times \frac{20}{60}}{\left ( \frac{140-30-20-20}{60} \right )} \\ &=7.2475 mm/hr \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 The probability that the annual maximum flood discharge will exceed 25000 [latex]m^3/s[/latex], at least once in next 5 years is found to be 0.25. The return period of this flood event (in years, round off to 1 decimal place) is ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Risk} &=1-q^n \\ 0.25&=1-q^5 \\ q&=0.944087 \\ 1-p&=0.944087 \\ 1-\frac{1}{T}&=0.944087 \\ T&\simeq 17.9 \; \text{years} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 A catchment may be idealised as a rectangle. There are three rain gauges located inside the catchment at arbitrary locations. The average precipitation over the catchment is estimated by two methods: (i) Arithmetic mean ([latex]P_A[/latex]), and (ii) Thiessen polygon ([latex]P_T[/latex]). Which one of the followingstatements is correct?
solution:
The result from Thiessen polygon method is more accurate than arithmetic mean method.
But there is no any close relationship between values obtained by Thiessen polygon method and Arithmetic mean method. Therefore, there is no any relation between [latex]P_A[/latex] and [latex]P_T[/latex].

options.D: There is no definite relationship between [latex]P_A \; and \; P_T[/latex]

question: Question 34 The total rainfall in a catchment of area [latex]1000\: km^{2}[/latex], during a 6 h storm, is 19 cm. The surface runoff due to this storm computed from triangular direct runoff hydrograph is [latex]1 \times 10^8 m^{3}[/latex]. The [latex]\phi _{index}[/latex] for this storm (in cm/h, up to one decimal place) is ______
solution: Surface runoff [latex]=\frac{1\times 10^{8}m^{3}}{1000\times 10^{6}m^{2}} =0.1 m=10 cm [/latex] Total rainfall = 19cm Rainfall intensity [latex]=\frac{19}{6}=3.167 cm/hr[/latex] w-Index [latex]= \frac{P-Q}{t}   =\frac{\text{Total Infiltration}}{\text{Total duration of storm}} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\; w-Index=\frac{19-10}{6}=1.5 cm/hr[/latex] As intensity of rainfall [latex] \gt [/latex]w-Index And rainfall intensity is uniform therefore [latex]\phi[/latex]-index = w-Index= 1.5 cm/hr.

question: Question 35 A culvert is designed for a flood frequency of 100 years and a useful life of 20 years. The risk involved in the design of the culvert (in percentage, up to two decimal places) is______
solution: Risk = The probabality of a flood to occur at least once in n-successive years. [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \;\; \text{Risk }&=1-q^{n} \\  &=1-\left ( 1-P \right )^{n} \\  &=1-\left ( 1-\frac{1}{T} \right )^{n} \\ &=1-\left ( 1-\frac{1}{100} \right )^{20} \\  &=1-\left ( 0.99 \right )^{20} \\ &=0.18209=18.209\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 The infiltration rate f in a basin under ponding condition is given by [latex]f=30+10e^{-2t}[/latex], where, f is in mm/h and t is time in hour. Total depth of infiltration (in mm, up to one decimal place) during the last 20 minutes of a storm of 30 minutes duration is ______
solution: Infiltration rate [latex]f(t)= 30+10e^{-2t}[/latex] Total infiltration depth in time 10 min. to 30 min. i.e., 0.166 hour to 0.5 hour [latex]=\int_{0.166}^{0.5}\left ( 30+10e^{-2t} \right )dt =11.74 mm  [/latex]

question: Question 37 Rainfall depth over a watershed is monitored through six number of well distributed rain gauges. Gauged data are given below The Thiessen mean value (in mm, up to one decimal place) of the rainfall is ______
solution: Thiessen mean value of rainfall; [latex]P_{avg}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{6}P_{i}A_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{6}A_{i}} [/latex] [latex] P_{avg}=\frac{470\times 95+465\times 100+435\times 98+525\times 80+480\times 85+510\times 92}{95+100+98+80+85+92} =479.09 mm[/latex]

question: Question 38 For routing of flood in a given channel using the Muskingum method, two of the routing coefficients are estimated as [latex]C_{0}=-0.25[/latex] and [latex]C_{1}= 0.55[/latex]. The value of the third coefficient [latex]C_{2}[/latex] would be ______
solution: In Muskingum flood routing method [latex]\begin{aligned}C_{0}+C_{1}+C_{2}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; C_{2}&=1-\left ( -0.25 \right )-0.55=0.7 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 A catchment is idealized as a 25 km x 25 km square. It has five rain gauges, one at each corner and one at the center, as shown in the figure. During a month, the precipitation at these gauges is measured as [latex]G_{1}[/latex] = 300 mm, [latex]G_{2}[/latex] = 285 mm, [latex]G_{3}[/latex] = 272mm, [latex]G_{4}[/latex] = 290mm and [latex]G_{5}[/latex] = 288mm. The average precipitation (in mm, up to one decimal place) over the catchment during this month by using the Thiessen polygon method is ______
solution: Let sides of square as, a=25 km Now area of the polygon is calculated as, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1}&=A_{2}=A_{3}=A_{4} \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\times \frac{a}{2}\times \frac{a}{2} \\ &=\frac{a^{2}}{8}=\frac{25^{2}}{8}=78.125 \\ A_{5}&=\text{Area of square of sides } \frac{\sqrt{2}a}{2} \\ &=\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}   =\frac{a^{2}}{2}=\frac{25^{2}}{2}=312.5\, km^{2} \\ \therefore & \text{Mean precipitation,}\\ \bar{P}&=\frac{G_{1}A_{1}+G_{2}A_{2}+G_{3}A_{3}+G_{4}A_{4}+G_{5}A_{5}}{A_{1}+A_{2}+A_{3}+A_{4}+A_{5}} \\ \therefore \;\;\bar{P}&=\frac{\left ( 300+255+272+290 \right )\times 78.125+288\times 312.5}{\left ( 4\times 78.125 \right )+312.5} \\  &= 287.375 mm\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The infiltration capacity of a soil follows the Horton's exponential model, [latex]f=c_{1}+c_{2} e^{-kt}[/latex]. During and experiment, the initial infiltration capacity was observed to be 200 mm/h. After a long time, the infiltration capacity was reduced to 25 mm/h. If the infiltration capacity after 1 hour was 90 mm/h, the value of the decay rate constant, k (in [latex]h^{-1}[/latex], up to two decimal places) is____
solution: Horton's expression for infiltration capacity of a soil is given as, [latex]f=C_{1}+C_{2}.e^{-kt}[/latex] Here, [latex]C_{1}=[/latex] Constant or steady stage infiltration capacity [latex]  C_{2}=[/latex] Difference between initial and steady stage infiltration capacity [latex]=\left ( f_{0}-f_{c} \right ) [/latex] [latex] f= [/latex] Infiltration capacity of any time 't' [latex]\therefore \;\;  f_{p}=f_{c}+\left ( f_{0}-f_{c} \right )e^{-k_{h}t} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; 90=25+\left ( 200-25 \right )e^{-k_{h}1} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; k_{h}=0.9904\, hr^{-1}[/latex]

question: Question 41 During a storm event in a certain period, the rainfall intensity is 3.5 cm/hour and the [latex]\Phi[/latex]-index is 1.5 cm/hour. The intensity of effective rainfall (in cm/hour, up to one decimal place) for this period is
solution: Let the rainfall duration is 't' hours [latex]\therefore[/latex] Total rainfall =3.5 cm/hr [latex]\times t[/latex] hr =3.5 t Total infitration = [latex]\phi[/latex]-index [latex]\times t[/latex] =1.5 t [latex]\therefore[/latex] Intensity of rainfall excess [latex]=\frac{\text{Total rainfall excess}}{\text{Time period}} [/latex] [latex]=\frac{3.5t-1.5t}{t}[/latex] cm/hr =2.0 cm/hr

question: Question 42 An effective rainfall of 2-hour duration produced a flood hydrograph peak of 200 [latex] m^{3}/s [/latex]. The flood hydrograph has a base flow of 20 [latex] m^{3}/s [/latex]. If the spatial average rainfall in the watershed for the duration of storm is 2 cm and the average loss rate is 0.4 cm/hour, the peak of 2-hour unit hydrograph (in [latex] m^{3}/s-cm [/latex], up to one decimal place) is _____
solution: Peak of 2 hr direct runoff hydrograph = Peak of 2 hr flood hydrograph-Base flow =200-20 =180 [latex]m^{3}/sec. [/latex] The rainfall excess depth for a given duration of 2 hr effective storm/rainfall is given by, Rainfall excess depth [latex] =2 cm-0.4 \frac{cm}{hr}\times 2 hr[/latex] [latex] =1.2 cm[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]Peak of 2 hr UH [latex]=\frac{180}{1.2}=150 m^{3}/s-cm[/latex]

question: Question 47 The average surface area of a reservoir in the month of June is 20 [latex]km^{2}[/latex]. In the same month, the average rate of inflow is 10 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s, outflow rate is 15 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s, monthly rainfall is 10 cm, monthly seepage loss is 1.8 cm and the storage change is 16 million [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The evaporation (in cm) in that month is
solution: Let 'x' cm evaporation takes place in month of June. Total inflow [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\left(\frac{10 \times 30 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60}{20 \times 10^{6}} \times 100\right)+10 \\ =139.6 \mathrm{cm} \end{array}[/latex] Total outflow [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\left(\frac{15 \times 30 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60}{20 \times 10^{6}} \times 100\right)+1.8+x\\ =196.2+x \mathrm{cm} \end{array}[/latex] As total outflow is more than total inflow, therefore depression in storage takes place. Depression in storage [latex] \begin{aligned} =-\frac{16 \times 10^{6}}{20 \times 10^{6}} \times 100&=-80 \mathrm{cm} \\ \Rightarrow 139.6-(196.2+x)&=-80 \\ -x &=-80+56.6\\ \therefore \quad x&=23.4 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 In a catchment, there are four rain-gauge stations, P, Q, R, and S. Normal annual precipitation values at these stations are 780 mm, 850 mm, 920 mm, and 980 mm respectively. In the year 2013, stations Q, R, and S, were operative but P was not. Using the normal ratio method, the precipitation at station P for the year 2013 has been established as 860 mm. If the observed precipitation at station Q and R for the year 2013 were 930 mm and 1010 mm, respectively; what was the observed precipitation (in mm) at station S for that year?
solution: Let [latex]P_{p}=[/latex] Precipitation in 2013 at station P [latex] N_{p}=[/latex] Noramal annual precipitation at station P [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{P_{p}}{N_{p}}&=\frac{1}{3}\left [ \frac{P_{Q}}{N_{q}}+\frac{P_{R}}{N_{R}}+\frac{P_{S}}{N_{S}} \right ]\\ \frac{860}{780}&=\frac{1}{3}\left [ \frac{930}{850}+\frac{1010}{920}+\frac{P_{S}}{980} \right ] \\ \Rightarrow \;\; P_{s}&=1093.43 mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 Ordinates of a 1-hour unity hydrograph at 1 hour intervals, starting from time t = 0 are 0, 2, 6, 4, 2, 1 and 0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]. Catchment area represented by this unit hydrograph is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Volume of } \mathrm{UH} &=60 \times 60 \times 1 \\ & \times(0+2+6+4+2+1+0\\ &=54000 \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ \therefore \text { Catchment area } &\times 1 \times 10^{-2}=54000\\ \Rightarrow \text { Catchment area }&=\frac{54000}{100}=5.4 \mathrm{km}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 72 An isolated 4-hour storm occurred over a catchment as follows : The [latex]\phi[/latex] index for the catchment is 10 mm/h. The estimated runoff depth from the
catchment due to the above storm is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi-index &=\frac{\text { Total Infiltration }}{\text { Time of rainfall excess }} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 10&=\frac{(28+12)-\text { Runoff }}{\text { Time of rainfall excess }} \end{aligned}[/latex] But precipitation in the [latex] 1^{\text {st }}[/latex] and [latex]4^{\text {th }}[/latex] hours is less than the [latex] \phi[/latex]-index i.e. the rainfall during these two hours is ineffective which means time of rainfall excess will be 2 hrs. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad 10&=\frac{40-\text { Runoff }}{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \text{ Runoff }&=20 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 For a catchment, the S-curve (or S-hydrograph) due to a rainfall of intensity 1 cm/hr is given by [latex]Q=1-(1+t)exp(-t)[/latex] (t in hr and Q in [latex]m^3/s[/latex]) What will be the ordinate of a 2-hour unit hydrograph for this catchment at t=3 hours ?
solution: The duration of S_curve =1 hr The ordinate of 2-hr UH is obtained by the following procedure: Step 1: The ordinate of S-curve at t=3 hr [latex]S_3=1-(1-3)e^{-3}=0.8m^3/s[/latex] Step 2: The ordinate of S-curve at [latex]t=3-2=1 \;hr[/latex] [latex]S_1=1-(1+1)e^{-1}=0.26m^3/s[/latex] Step 3: [latex]S_3-S_1=0.8-0.26=0.54m^3/s[/latex] Step 4: The ordinate of UH at t=3 hr is [latex]\frac{S_3-S_2}{2}=0.27 m^3/s[/latex]

question: Question 74 For a catchment, the S-curve (or S-hydrograph) due to a rainfall of intensity 1 cm/hr is given by [latex]Q=1-(1+t)exp(-t)[/latex] (t in hr and Q in [latex]m^3/s[/latex]) What is the area of the catchment ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Volume of } \mathrm{UH} &=60 \times 60 \times 1 \\ & \times(0+2+6+4+2+1+0\\ &=54000 \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ \therefore \text { Catchment area } &\times 1 \times 10^{-2}=54000\\ \Rightarrow \text { Catchment area }&=\frac{54000}{100}=5.4 \mathrm{km}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] The saturation discharge of S-curve, [latex]Q_S=\lim_{t \to \infty }Q[/latex] [latex]Q_S=1m^3/s[/latex] Rainfall intensity, [latex]i=1\; cm/hr=\frac{1}{360000}m/s[/latex] [latex]\therefore\; \text{ Catchment area }\times i=Q_S[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\text{ Catchment area }=\frac{1}{1/360000}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\text{ Catchment area }=360000m^2=0.36km^2[/latex]

question:
Question 75 During a 3 hour storm event, it was observed that all abstractions other than
infiltration are negligible. The rainfall was idealized as 3 one hour storms of
intensity 10 mm/hr, 20 mm/hr and 10 mm/hr respectively and the infiltration
was idealized as a Horton curve, [latex]f = 6.8 + 8.7 exp(- t)[/latex] (f in mm/hr and t in hr). 
What is the effective rainfall ?
solution: From superposition of hyetograph and infiltration curve it is clear that first hour does not contribute to effective rainfall (i.e. rainfall excess). For t=1 to t=3, the effective rainfall is, [latex]\begin{aligned} r_e&=20+10-\int_{1}^{3} (6.8+8.7e^{-t})dt\\ &=30-\left [ (6.8t)_1^3+8.7 \int_{1}^{3}e^{-t} dt\right ] \\ &= 30-[6.8 \times 2 -8.7(e^{-t})_1^3]\\ &=30-13.6+8.7\left [ \frac{1}{e^3}-\frac{1}{e^1} \right ] \\ &= 16.4-2.77\\ &= 13.63mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 76 A four hour unit hydrograph of a catchment is triangular in shape with base of

30[latex]m^3/s[/latex] and 1mm/h, respectively. A storm of 4cm occurs uniformly in 4 hours

solution: Depth of precipitation =4 cm Infiltration in 4 hrs [latex]  =4\times 1 =4 mm =0.4 cm[/latex] Run off depth [latex]=4-0.4=3.6 cm[/latex] Peak of DRH of 4 hrs [latex]  =50\times 3.6 =180m^{3}/sec[/latex] Peak of flood discharge, [latex]  Q=180+30 =210m^{3}/sec[/latex]

question:
Question 78 When the outflow from a storage reservoir is uncontrolled as in a freely operating
spillway, the peak of outflow hydrograph occurs at
solution: When outflow from a reservoir is uncontrolled as in freely operating spillway, then the peak of outflow hydrograph will occur at a point of intersection of inflow and outflow curves, whereas if outflow from a reservoir is controlled then peak will occur after the intersection of the curve.

options.A: the point of inter-section of the inflow and outflow hydrographs
options.B: a point, after the inter-section of the inflow and outflow hydrographs
options.D: a point, before the inter-section of the inflow and ouflow hydrographs

question: Question 79 The intensity of rainfall and time interval of a typical storm are : The maximum intensity of rainfall for 20 minutes duration of the storm is
solution: Maximum intensity [latex]=\frac{2.2\times 10+1.5\times 10}{10+10}=1.85 mm/minute[/latex]

question:
Question 80 The average rainfall for a 3 hour duration storm is 2.7 cm and the loss rate is 0.3
cm/hr. The flood hydrograph has a base flow of 20[latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s and produces a peak flow of 210 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s. The peak of a 3-h unity hydrograph is
solution: Rainfall excess [latex]=2.7-0.3 \times 3 =1.8 [/latex] cm Peak discharge of DRH [latex]= 210-20=190 m^{3}/s [/latex] Peak of 3-h UH [latex]=\frac{190}{1.8}=105.55 m^{3}/s[/latex]

question:
Question 81 The rainfall during three successive 2 hour periods are 0.5, 2.8 and 1.6 cm. The
surface runoff resulting from this storm is 3.2 cm. The [latex]\phi[/latex] index value of this storm is
solution: Total rainfall = 0.5+2.8+1.6&=4.9 cm Excess rainfall =4.9+3.2&=1.7 cm Taking excess rainfall duration, [latex]  t_{e}=2\times 3=6[/latex] hrs [latex]\phi[/latex]-index = [latex]\frac{1.7}{6}=0.28[/latex]cm/hr This value being more than [latex]\frac{0.5}{2}=0.25[/latex] cm/hr, the excess rainfall duration will reduce by 2-hrs. [latex]\therefore \;\; t_{e}=[/latex]4 hrs Excess rainfall = 2.8 +1.6-3.2 =1.2 cm [latex]\phi[/latex]-index [latex]=\frac{1.2}{4}=0.3[/latex] cm/hr

question:
Question 82 An average rainfall of 16 cm occurs over a catchment during a period of 12 hours
with a uniform intensity. The unit hydrograph (unit depth = 1cm, duration = 6
hours) of the catchment rises linearly from 0 to 30 cumecs in six hours and then
falls linearly from 30 to 0 cumecs in the next 12 hours. [latex]\phi[/latex] index of the catchment
is known to be 0.5 cm/hr. Base flow in the river is known to be 5 cumecs. Area of the catchment in hectares is
solution: Catchment area[latex]\times[/latex] rainfall excess =Area under UH [latex] \begin{aligned} A\times \frac{1}{100}&=\frac{30\times 18\times 60\times 60}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;A&=9720\times 10^{4}m^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; A&=9720 ha\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 83 An average rainfall of 16 cm occurs over a catchment during a period of 12 hours
with a uniform intensity. The unit hydrograph (unit depth = 1cm, duration = 6
hours) of the catchment rises linearly from 0 to 30 cumecs in six hours and then
falls linearly from 30 to 0 cumecs in the next 12 hours. [latex]\phi[/latex] index of the catchment
is known to be 0.5 cm/hr. Base flow in the river is known to be 5 cumecs. Peak discharge of the resulting direct runoff hydrograph shall be
solution: The DRH of the storm of 12 hours can be prepared by superimposing another 6-hr UH lagged by 6-hr. Rainfall excess [latex]=16-0.5 \times 12=10 cm[/latex] Peak discharge of resulting direct runoff is given by, [latex]Q_{P}=22.5 \times \text{rainfall excess } [/latex] [latex] \;\; =22.5\times 10=225[/latex] cumecs

question: Question 84 Match the following:

Question 85 The plan area of a reservoir is 1 [latex]km^{2}[/latex]. The water level in the reservoir is observed to decline by 20 cm in certain period. During this period the reservoir receives a surface inflow of 10 hectare-meters, and 20 hectare-meters are abstracted
from the reservoir for irrigation and power. The plan evaporation and rainflow
recorded during the same period at a nearby meteorological station are 12 cm
and 3 cm respectively. The calibrated pan factor is 0.7. The seepage loss from the
reservoir during the this period in hectare-meters is
solution: Inflow to reservoir, I= 10 ha-m Outflow from reservoir, Q=20 ha-m Evaporation loss, [latex]E=1\times 10^{6}\times \frac{12}{100}\times 0.7 =8.4 ha-m[/latex] Rainfall,  [latex]P=1\times 10^{6}\times \frac{3}{100} =3 ha-m[/latex] Change in storage, [latex]\Delta S=1\times 10^{6}\times \frac{20}{100} =-20 ha-m[/latex] We know that, [latex](I+P)-(E+Q+\text{Seepage})=\Delta S [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;  (10+3)-(8.4+20+\text{Seepage})=-20 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 13-28.4-\text{Seepage} = -20 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \text{Seepage} =4.6 ha-m[/latex]

question:
Question 86 While applying the Rational formula for computing the design discharge, the
rainfall duration is stipulated as the time of concentration because
solution: Time of concentration is the time when whole catchment starts contributing to runoff at the outlet.

options.A: this leads to the largest possible rainfall intensity
options.B: this leads to the smallest possible rainfall intensity
options.C: the time of concentration is the smallest rainfall duration for which the Rational formula is applicable
options.D:
the time of concentration is the largest rainfall duration for which the
Rational formula is applicable

question:
Question 87 The vertical hydraulic conductivity of the top soil at certain stage is 0.2 cm/hr. A storm of intensity 0.5 cm/hr occurs over the soil for an indefinite period.
Assuming the surfaces drainage to be adequate, the infiltration rate after the
storm has lasted for a very long time, shall be
solution: Permeability = Hydraulic conductivity [latex]\left ( \frac{\mu }{\rho g} \right )[/latex] A storm of i=0.5 cm/hr occurs over the soil for an indefinite period. What is the meaning of "indefinite period"? In order to achieve steady state condition, continuous application of water is necessary so that the water level is maintained constant. 'Surface drainage adequate' means at steady state condition some water flows as surface runoff. 'Storm has lasted for a very long time' means the hydraulic conductivity approaches saturated hydraulic conductivity (so that Darcy's law can be obeyed) and at steady state condition infiltration rate is also constant. The constant infiltration rate which is achieved after very long time, shall be more than 0.2 cm/hr (as hydraulic conductivity has increased) but should be less than storm intensity 0.5 cm/hr due to adequate drainage.

question:
Question 88 The rainfall on five successive days in a catchment were measured as 3, 8, 12, 6,
and 2 cms. If the total runoff at the outlet from the catchment was 15 cm, the
value of the [latex]\phi[/latex]-index (in mm/hour) is
solution: W-index [latex]=\frac{P-Q}{t}=\frac{\left ( 3+8+12+6+2 \right )-15}{5} =3.2 cm/day[/latex] Now, as [latex]\phi[/latex]-index [latex]\geq[/latex] w-Index [latex]\therefore[/latex] The rainfall of magnitude 3 cm and 2 cm will not participate in rainfall excess depth (i.e., these will completely infiltrate) [latex]\therefore[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi-index&= \frac{\text{Infiltration during rainfall excess depth}}{\text{Time period of rainfall excess}} \\   &=\frac{\left ( 8+12+6 \right )-15}{3}=3.67cm/day\\ \text{i.e., } &=\frac{3.67\times 10}{24} mm/hr=1.525 mm/hr \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

question: Question 93 Isopleths are lines on a map through points having equal depth of
solution: The mean annual PET (in cm) over various parts of the country is shown in the form of isopleths. Isopleths are the line on a map through places having equal depth of "evapotranspiration".

question:
Question 94 The stage-discharge relation in a river during the passage of flood is measured.
If [latex]q_f[/latex] is the discharge at the stage when water surface is falling and [latex]q_r[/latex] is the
discharge at the same stage when water surface is rising, then
solution: At the same stage, more discharge passes through the river during rising stages than in falling ones. Note: Stage discharge relation is also known as rating curve.
